slides.title: Introduction to Product Model Availability
slides.notes: Welcome to the lesson on Product Model Availability in PolicyCenter. We'll explore how availability is configured and how it impacts what users can see and do in the application.
slides.narration: Welcome to our session on Product Model Availability in PolicyCenter. As a developer, understanding how availability is configured is crucial since it directly affects what users can access and interact with in the application. Today, we'll dive into the various mechanisms for setting availability and the practical implications these configurations have.
slides.ocrText: Product Model: Availability

slides.title: Understanding Availability
slides.notes: Availability in PolicyCenter ensures that certain patterns, like coverages, are either visible or hidden from users based on specific criteria.
slides.narration: So, what exactly do we mean by availability in PolicyCenter? Essentially, it's about controlling whether specific patterns, such as coverages, appear in the user interface. If a pattern is marked as unavailable, users won't be able to create instances of it, ensuring the application remains streamlined and relevant to the policy.

slides.title: Availability Mechanisms
slides.notes: PolicyCenter uses availability tables, scripts, and grandfathering to manage product model availability. These tools provide flexibility in defining how and when patterns are accessible.
slides.narration: Now let's look at how availability is actually managed within PolicyCenter. We use availability tables, scripts, and the concept of grandfathering to determine what patterns are accessible. This provides us with the flexibility to tailor product offerings to meet specific business needs and regulatory requirements.

slides.title: Configuring Availability in the Product Model
slides.originalNotes:
Availability in the product model
Availability in the user interface means that a coverage, or any other pattern on which the availability is set, either shows up or does not show up in the application.

If a pattern is unavailable, PolicyCenter does not expose that pattern and does not permityou to create instances from the pattern.

slides.narration: When configuring availability, we have three main options: the Availability Table, Availability Script, and Grandfather States. The availability lookup table is often preferred due to its extendibility and performance benefits. It allows for complex configurations to accommodate factors like state and class code, ensuring that our product offerings align with business and compliance requirements.

slides.title: Patterns with Availability Logic
slides.originalNotes:
Configuring availability in product model
There are three options for availability for a product model pattern. The three options are Availability Table, Availability Script, and Grandfather States. The Availability lookup table is the preferred way to configure availability. The lookup tables can be extended to include more factors, such as the class code. Refer to the PolicyCenter configuration guide document for more details.

A product model pattern may be grandfathered, meaning that it is available if it already exists on a policy, even if it is unavailable according to both its availability table and script. This permits product model entities to remain on a policy even past their "normal" expiration dates, but once the entity is removed from the policy it cannot be added back. Grandfathering may be restricted to a certain set of states. Grandfathering is discussed later in this lesson.

The offerings are different flavors of a product, where you can enable or disable parts of the product in an offering.

slides.narration: It's important to note that every pattern in the product model includes availability logic with the exception of policy line patterns. Why is this? Policy line patterns are intricately linked to the product itself, so their availability is inherently determined at the product level. This means that when a product is available, its associated policy line pattern automatically is as well.

slides.title: Determining Entity Availability
slides.originalNotes:
Patterns with availability logic
All of the product model patterns have availability logic, except for policy line patterns.

There is no availability for policy line patterns because policy line patterns are so closely tied to products that availability logic would almost always be stored at the product level. If a product is available then it will always have an underlying policy line pattern. Note that Modifier patterns provide additional information for the rating engine to use to adjustthe policy premium (or some portion of the premium).

The availability for product level patterns can be set through lookup table only.

slides.narration: Determining whether a product model entity is available involves several steps. PolicyCenter first checks the lookup table for potential entities, then applies any availability scripts to further refine this list. These scripts are written in Gosu and help ensure that only the most relevant entities are accessible, streamlining the user experience.

slides.title: Availability Scripts
slides.notes: Scripts must return a Boolean value and can be complex, impacting performance. They are written in Gosu and should be validated in Studio.
slides.narration: Availability scripts are a powerful tool in our configuration arsenal. These scripts, written in Gosu, must return a true or false value and are used to further refine entity availability. While they offer flexibility, it's crucial to keep them efficient, as overly complex scripts can degrade performance. Remember, Product Designer won't validate these scripts, so always use Studio to ensure they compile correctly.

slides.title: Grandfathering When Discontinuing a Coverage
slides.originalNotes:
Determining availability of an entity
PolicyCenter controls the availability of an entity through the use of the following mechanisms: lookup tables, availability scripts, grandfathering, and offerings. To determine if a particular product model entity is available, PolicyCenter first consults the appropriate lookup table to determine the initial set S ofavailable entities. The set S may be a restricted subset of all thepossible entities named in the product model. After PolicyCenter determines the initial set of available entities it applies an availability script, if one exists, to each member of S to filter out more elements. The availability script is a Boolean-value Gosu expression used to limit the available elements. This availability script may be empty, in which case PolicyCenter considers all elements of S available. The availability scriptonly reduces which entities are available from within PolicyCenter.

slides.narration: Grandfathering is an interesting concept that allows us to manage the lifecycle of product model patterns. If a coverage is discontinued, grandfathering ensures it remains available on existing policies, even if it can't be added to new ones. This approach balances continuity for existing customers with the need to retire obsolete offerings.

slides.title: Renewals with Grandfathered Coverages
slides.notes: Renewals in California are allowed due to grandfathering, even after initial availability has ended.
slides.narration: Renewal scenarios become particularly interesting with grandfathered coverages. For instance, in California, even if a policy's effective date is after the general unavailability date, the grandfathering rule allows for coverage renewals. This ensures that policies align with regulatory and business expectations without disrupting existing customer agreements.

slides.title: Availability Data Reloading
slides.originalNotes:
Grandfathering when discontinuing a coverage
A product model pattern may be grandfathered, meaning that it is available if it alreadyexists on a policy, even if it is unavailable according to both its availability table and script. This means that productmodel entities stay on a policy past their "normal“ expiration date, After the entity is removed from the policy, it cannot be addedback to the policy. Grandfathering may be restricted to certain states or a set of states.

Grandfathering use cases: Unavailable for all use. Not all discontinued patterns will be grandfathered. Sometimes the insurer cannot support the existing pattern and discontinues Use. In this case, the pattern is not available at the next renewal period for existing business or to any new businesses, butit is available for policy changes on the existing period for existing business. The existing reference date lookup logic is taking care of this appropriately already. Unavailable for new business, grandfathered if already in use.
In the case of grandfathering, whether or not an existing coverage can continue to be used is filed with language indicating that the coverage will be allowed to continue where it is already in use, but there will be no new usages. In this scenario, the decision of whether the pattern isavailable is make on a policy- by-policy basis, strictly depending upon whether the coverage is already present on the policy.

slides.title: Availability data: reloading
slides.originalNotes:
Availability data: reloading
Availability lookup tables, availability scripts, and grandfathering define the criteria for product model pattern availability on a policy entity. Product Designer stores them and writes them to XML files in the configuration module. are reloaded against a running server in production. A specific example for dynamically reloading in the product documentation (search ZReloading Availability Example").

Reloading the availability data performs a sync between the lookup XML files and the lookup entities in the database. New lookups in the XML files will be added to the database, changes to existing lookups will be applied to the database, and existing lookups which no longer appear in the XML files will be removed from the database. This implies that the external lookup directory must contain a complete set of lookups for the entire product model, for instance it is not possible to update lookups for a single coverage by including a single XML file in the external directory.

 Invalid lookups can corrupt the database, but this will not occur in practice if configuration users use Product Designer to manage and verify the lookup tables. Press Alt + Shift + T to go to Internal tools / Server tools page.

slides.title: Demonstration
slides.originalNotes:
Demonstration
Advantages of an Availability Table: can be extended, performance is better than scripts, table is a set of 1 to many rows. Each row defines a criteria that can be based on a date, state and in some cases industry and product- True or false values of rows determine whether a pattern is available.

Additional details: Availability lookup tables permit only relatively simple equality comparisons, so product model patterns can also specify an availability script to handle more complex conditions. For example, a script would be necessary if a coverage pattern is available only for vehicles manufactured after 1986, since this is not a straight equality check. A script may only further restrict table- based availability results; if a pattern is unavailable according to the lookup table,then the script will not even execute.

The columns in an availability table, such as start effective date, end effective date, and job type, are called dimensions. In addition, a column called Availability designates whether a pattern that matches the row is Available or Unavailable- When evaluating a pattern, PolicyCenter finds the row in the availability table that matches best, and then uses the state of the Availability cell in that row. The best matching row is the row that matches the mostdimensions. If multiple rows match the same number of dimensions, the precedence of the dimensions determines the row that determines availability. Omitted dimensions are wildcards that match any value. If no rows match any defined dimension, the pattern is made unavailable.
